body.name: Black Girls Must Be Magic: A Novel
body.description: “Masterfully written and pitch perfect, Black Girls Must Be Magic is, simply, magic.”—Good Morning AmericaIn this highly anticipated second installment in the Black Girls Must Die Exhausted series, Tabitha Walker copes with more of life’s challenges and a happy surprise—a baby—with a little help and lots of love from friends old and new.For Tabitha Walker, her grandmother’s old adage, “Black girls must die exhausted” is becoming all too true. Discovering she’s pregnant—after she was told she may not be able to have biological children—Tabitha throws herself headfirst into the world of “single mothers by choice.” Between her job, doctor’s appointments, and preparing for the baby, she’s worn out. And that’s before her boss at the local news station starts getting complaints from viewers about Tabitha’s natural hair.When an unexpected turn of events draws Marc—her on and off-again ex-boyfriend—back into her world with surprising demands, and the situation at work begins to threaten her livelihood and her identity, Tabitha must make some tough decisions about her and her baby’s future. It takes a village to raise a child, and Tabitha turns to the women who have always been there for her.Bolstered by the fierce support of Ms. Gretchen, her grandmother’s best friend, the counsel of her closest friends Laila and Alexis, and the calming presence of her doula Andouele, Tabitha must find a way to navigate motherhood on her own terms. Will she harness the bravery, strength, and self-love she’ll need to keep “the village” together, find her voice at work, and settle things with Marc before the baby arrives? Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I’m so glad that I read this book immediately after the other one, as it was the same m author. I wasn’t aware that it was a continuation of the story, which is really really a good surprise.I definitely recommend reading Black Girls Die Exhausted, before reading this one. This story is so relatable and easy to read and a lovely story I truly enjoyed it. Off to read the next book ❤️

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Rooting for Tab and Marc
reviews.reviewText: I’m rooting for Tabitha’s happy ending. I hope she finds that Marc is the one for her despite his Patents.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars awesome part two
reviews.reviewText: I was eager to start this book, I looked everyone and nobody had it. I read it in my kindle and I’m so glad I did. It feels like you know the characters personally and it’s a page turner. Both books I have completed in less than a week. This one I started and then put it down. Today I was in a training started reading and completed it by the end of the night. Now to read the last book of the series! I enjoyed the book so far.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars I loved this one even more
reviews.reviewText: This sequel to Black Girls Must Be Exhausted was really filled with joy. Can’t wait to start the next in the series.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Black girl must be magic
reviews.reviewText: I ended up purchasing the whole series of Jayne Allen books 📚. The books including Black girl must be magic is the second book in the series was amazing.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This book series is phenomenal. As a black woman, I can relate to all of the feelings, emotions, & issues that appeared in the book. I look forward to reading more books by this author!!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I loved the first book. Very relatable. I enjoyed Tabby slowly growing into herself (BOUT TIME 😆) in this book. Being pregnant is making her view and face things I think she probably wouldn't have faced on her own. I look forward to seeing how she faces motherhood.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars It’s written for all women regardless of race or age!
reviews.reviewText: review of Black Girls must be exhaustedI really loved these books! I loved the characters . Tabitha and her friends and Tabitha’s desire to find out out what she really wanted and needed. She didn’t fall for the fantasy society feeds us about getting a man and having happiness ever after. She was thoughtful and willing to take risks to achieve what she wanted.I have always thought Black women carried the most baggage and got the least support. In this book you feel that stress before she even gets to work in the morning. I could relate to that daily stress and the struggle to balance it all. It keeps you guessing how it will all be resolved. I want a 4th book aboutTabby cat and how she manageswith the baby , the job and future relations. I so love the strength of her friendships and how that’s what carried her through her life.Excellent writing! Funny, compassionate and thought provoking!I also liked the development of relationships without mentioning race . The author shows us how relationships are developed regardless of racial differences by putting in the time to really know a person and their unique struggles. By learning about a person you are more tolerant of their differences and work harder to understand and be understood.Bonnie Davis Miller, Phd

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 22, 2023
reviews.reviewText: The book is slow in parts but then picks up enough to keep you engaged and wanting to read more so at this point I’m invested and ready for book 3!
